either physics, first principles,

you are interested in measuring or estimating,

that describes your system, um,
and you would observe y and your goal is to guess x.

when you- if you know y,
um, and you know, uh,
if- if you know y, you know A,

you can look at y equals, uh,
Ax, um, and you're- you're basically guessing what v is at that point, right?
So- so v is y minus Ax.
And- and basic least scores estimation it goes like this.
We will simply assume that this noise vector is small.

0.1 degrees C or something like that.

Okay. Um, and so here's least squares estimation.
You are going to guess x by minimizing,
ah, norm, uh, Ax minus y.
Now, let's note what that is.
Ax is what our model says,
y would be without noise.
Um, y is what we actually observed.
And so this says, please choose me an x for which
the- our model would-model output would
match as closely as possible what we actually measured.
So that's an- that's- that's least squares estimation.
And it's completely normal and makes- makes perfect, uh, perfect sense.
Um, I should also add that this vector is minus v. So another way to say it is,
please, choose an x so that, uh,
given the noise we observe that tells you what v is,
and that's the measurement noise, and you say,
please give me an x for which we have to imagine that the,
uh, measurement noise is very small- is small as possible.
So that's the least squares-least squares estimation.
Okay. [NOISE] Now, um,
sometimes when people do this- uh,
in fact, very frequently when people do this, ah,
they had regularization, and that's called either
regularized estimation- sometimes called regularized inversion,
um, something like that.
Um, and the way that works is you simply factor in to the problem you solve to guess x,
um, prior information about x.
And that prior could be things like this.
You think, well, I don't think x should be too large.
That's- that's what I think.
Um, or I think x should be smooth, something like that.
So you can have any- all sorts of priors here, right?

what we're gonna talk about here is- is good enough,

using things like a norm x squared the-
that- that mathematically expresses the prior that x is small.

and that's based on this name for a- a Russian mathematician Tikhonov.

[NOISE] J2 equals Dx,
where D is some kind of difference operator.

it's just done- it's ad-hoc.

it's the Dirichlet energy.

with the case of an image,
it's actually a sum of two norm squares.

um, tomographic reconstructions of the- of the transit times,

So what they had was, uh,
they don't know how long it takes, uh,
to go from this stop to this stop on a subway.
Um, but what they do have is they have, um,
the- sort of like the analog of line integrals because of
what they know is a passenger went into this subway,
this station, they took this train,
transferred, then took this train,
then transferred, took that train.
And what- they know when they clocked out at the other end.
So they actually know the sum of three.
And if you think carefully, that's kind of like- kind of like a line integral.
It's this sum of three things.
And so basically you have to extract from
various sums the individual values and that's the essential idea of tomography.
